body: Theater ''KING GILGAMESH'' combines theater, music and ethnic dancing in an epic story. At two Greenwich Village locations: Sunday at 8 p.m. at 73 Fifth Avenue, at 15th Street, Loft 11B; tickets, $15, which includes a reception; and Monday at 8 p.m. at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street; tickets, $10. Both shows are free
title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: CHILLE-Franz, M.D. On December 5, 2002. Devoted husband of 51 years to Constance (nee Cione). Loving father of Adele Frank and Darren and father-in-law of Cindy; adoring grandfather of Danielle and Michael Frank; loving brother - in - law of Frank (Cion) Cione; dedicated Bensonhurst, Brooklyn physician for 50 years. A man of all seasons. The
title: Paid Notice: Deaths CHILLE, FRANZ, M.D.

body: Some people are good at concealing their emotions. Sure, they worry -- about school, about family. But no one would know it by looking at them. But Max Noto wasn't like that. For him, worry was not only something he carried around on the inside. He wore it on the outside, too. When Max, 11, was worried, he broke out in a rash. He would have
title: The Neediest Cases; Cure for Boy's Skin Disorder Is Financial Stability

body: FOR CHILDREN Theater ''JACK,'' a futuristic musical based on ''Jack and the Beanstalk,'' presented by the Little Theater at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63rd Street, Manhattan. body: NIEPORENT - Lucille Iris (nee Pollack), died October 30th, 2002, at the Beth Israel Medical Center in New York, after a valiant struggle with lymphoma. Beloved wife of Dr. Hans. Loving mother of James, Darren and Amy. Devoted sister to Herbert. Devoted sister-in-law to Maja Niles. Graduate of Barnard College. Director of English Writing Center at
title: Paid Notice: Deaths NIEPORENT, LUCILLE IRIS (NEE POLLACK)

body: NEIL SIMON grew up in the Bronx, but it is Brighton Beach that he brought to the stage and screen when he recalled his 1930's boyhood in ''Brighton Beach Memoirs.'' The first act opens in ''a wooden frame house, not too far from the beach. It is a lower-middle-income area inhabited mostly by Jews, Irish and Germans.'' Today's gawky Eugene Jerome,
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Brighton Beach; Magnet for Immigrants, Moving Upscale

body: It was a strange journey. A conservative idea championed by liberals, it was embraced by its enemies and abandoned by its supposed beneficiaries. When it died in disgrace, its last defenders were the philosophical descendants of its original adversaries. It was school decentralization, for 33 years the guiding organizational principle of New York
title: The Odd Circle Of School Control; 'Power to the People' in 1960's Is Now Seen as 'Amateur Hour'

body: Theater ''WEST SIDE STORY,'' the classic musical of doomed young love, presented by the young members of the City Lights Youth Theater, 101 East 15th Street, Manhattan. title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: Storing sand on a beach hardly seems controversial. But some residents of Manhattan Beach and Brighton Beach in Brooklyn were angry to learn that the Army Corps of Engineers is considering their shores as storage for 250,000 cubic yards of sand, to be dredged from Rockaway Inlet this fall. ''The last thing we need here is more sand,'' said Ida
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK WATERFRONT; In Brighton Beach, Opposition to More Sand on the Sand

body: New Yorkers' favorite sounds? Judging from the response to our invitation last Sunday to name a memorable sound of the city, the clip-clop of horses' hooves ranked high, especially police horses, especially on cobblestones. Also much loved were the sounds of birds: red-tailed hawks on Fifth Avenue, finches on the West Side, sea gulls in Manhattan
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK VOICES; Finding the City's Sweet Music In Hoofbeats, Coffee Carts and Pining Bells

body: One after another, the school buses pulled up to the curb outside Brooklyn Borough Hall yesterday morning and disgorged their charges. But it was not student-appreciation day at the government center. Nearly all of the passengers were elderly, and several hundred of them wore bright yellow baseball caps. ''Gov. Pataki Please Help,'' the caps said.
title: Redistricting, and Lunch, Draw a Crowd
